skill.name: test-kitchen
skill.description: This skill should be used when implementing features with parallel exploration or competition. Triggers on "build", "create", "implement", "try both approaches", "compare implementations". Routes to omakase-off (entry gate for design exploration) or cookoff (exit gate for parallel implementation).
skill.summary: This skill should be used when implementing features with parallel exploration or competition. Trigg...
skill.author: 2389-research

security_audit.summary: Pure prompt-based skill containing only markdown documentation. No executable code, no file access, no network calls, and no environment variable access. All content is workflow guidance for AI-assisted development.

content.value_statement: Development teams often get stuck on architectural decisions or default to one approach without comparison. This skill provides gate skills that offer parallel exploration before implementation and competition during implementation. Multiple variants are built and tested, letting real results determine the best approach.
actual_capabilities: Entry gate that offers parallel design exploration before implementation begins
Exit gate that runs multiple agents implementing the same design in parallel
Passive detection of architectural indecision during brainstorming
Worktree-based isolation for parallel variant development
limitations: Requires other skills for actual implementation (writing-plans, executing-plans, scenario-testing)
Cannot run without a design document as the shared source of truth
Parallel variants limited to 5-6 maximum to avoid combinatorial explosion
User must select winner after judge evaluation

use_cases.title: Escape linear thinking
use_cases.description: When uncertain about an approach, explore multiple implementations simultaneously instead of committing to one path.

use_cases.title: Evaluate trade-offs objectively
use_cases.description: Let competing implementations reveal strengths and weaknesses rather than debating theory.

use_cases.title: Compare implementation styles
use_cases.description: See how different teams approach the same design to learn patterns and anti-patterns.

prompt_templates.title: Quick parallel build
prompt_templates.prompt: Build X using omakase-off. I want to see multiple approaches implemented in parallel.

prompt_templates.title: During brainstorming
prompt_templates.scenario: Detect indecision and offer parallel paths
prompt_templates.prompt: We are brainstorming the architecture. If the user shows uncertainty about key decisions, offer omakase-off parallel exploration.

prompt_templates.title: At implementation time
prompt_templates.prompt: We have a design document ready. How should we implement this? Present cookoff options for parallel implementation.

prompt_templates.title: Explicit competition
prompt_templates.prompt: Run a cookoff between 3 agents implementing this design. Each agent creates their own plan and implementation.

output_examples.input: Build a CLI todo app with test-kitchen
output: Before diving in, how would you like to approach this?
Option 1: Brainstorm together - explore requirements step by step
Option 2: Omakase - generate multiple approaches and implement them in parallel

best_practices: Use omakase-off when uncertain about architectural choices to explore multiple designs
Use cookoff when you have a clear design but want to compare implementation approaches
Always invoke the judge skill to get objective scoring before selecting a winner
anti_patterns: Using omakase-off for trivial decisions like file naming or config format
Sharing a pre-made implementation plan across agents in cookoff
Skipping fresh-eyes review or scenario testing before judge evaluation

faq.question: What is the difference between omakase-off and cookoff?
faq.answer: Omakase-off explores different DESIGNS before implementation. Cookoff implements the same DESIGN with different approaches.

faq.question: How many parallel implementations can I run?
faq.answer: Omakase-off caps at 5-6 variants. Cookoff recommends 2-5 based on feature complexity assessment.

faq.question: Does this skill execute code directly?
faq.answer: No. This is a prompt-based workflow skill. It orchestrates other skills for actual implementation.

faq.question: What happens to the losing implementations?
faq.answer: Worktrees and branches are automatically cleaned up. The winner branch is kept for merge or PR.

faq.question: Which skills does test-kitchen depend on?
faq.answer: It uses writing-plans, executing-plans, scenario-testing, fresh-eyes, and finish-branch skills if installed.

faq.question: Can I use this with existing brainstorming workflows?
faq.answer: Yes. Omakase-off detects indecision during existing brainstorming and offers parallel exploration as an option.
